key_channel_insights.line_content: OTA fares exceeded the website on 98.2% of itineraries last week, averaging a 0.50% markup with the largest gaps on short-haul and far-out bookings.
MSE offered lower fares on 95.96% of itineraries, delivering an average discount of 0.08%, while small portions of long-haul and non-PL markets saw markups.
GDS maintained a premium on 98.88% of itineraries at an average markup of 0.59%, with unavailability rising to 1.12% and far-out bookings showing the highest premiums.

conclusion.line_content: This report provides a high-level summary of the price discrepancies observed across different channels.  It is important to note that the data contains many nuances depending on various factors such as market conditions, booking windows, and the competitive landscape. Understanding these subtleties can be critical in optimizing pricing strategies and ensuring competitive positioning.

As part of our 'PriceEye' solution, we are developing an intuitive dashboard designed to help your airline's analysts drill down into this data. This tool will allow you to uncover and focus on critical actionable insights, enabling your team to make data-driven decisions with confidence.

We are here to support you in leveraging these insights to enhance your revenue management and distribution strategies. Please don't hesitate to connect with our team for more information about how PriceEye can assist you in achieving your business objectives.

ota_highlights.line_content: OTA fares were higher than the website on 98.2% of itineraries, maintaining a 0.50% average premium despite a slight 0.47ppt week-on-week decrease.
Short-haul itineraries saw a 0.55% OTA markup at 98.0% frequency, while long-haul routes had a negligible 0.03% premium at full coverage.
Far-out bookings exhibited 100% higher OTA fares with the largest average premium of 0.65%, highlighting stronger early-purchase leverage.

ota_summary_high_level_comparison.line_content: 1.8% of website fares were not listed on OTAs last week, up from 1.11% the prior week, indicating slightly reduced coverage.
No itineraries matched website fares on OTAs, consistent with persistent negligible parity levels.
OTAs did not undercut website prices on any itinerary, maintaining a 0% incidence of discounts.
98.2% of itineraries carried an OTA premium averaging 0.50%, with a marginal 0.47ppt week-on-week reduction.

ota_summary_by_region.line_content: Short-haul routes had 1.99% of fares missing on OTAs and 98.0% incidence of higher pricing, averaging a 0.55% premium.
Long-haul itineraries achieved full OTA coverage with premiums on all routes but only a 0.03% average markup.

ota_summary_by_point_of_origin.line_content: POOs in Poland saw 98.7% of fares priced higher on OTAs at a 0.56% average premium, with missing offers at 1.29%.
Non-PL origins had 5.36% of fares absent from OTAs and a reduced 94.6% premium frequency, delivering only a 0.07% average markup.

ota_summary_by_booking_window.line_content: Close-in bookings showed 97.4% higher OTA fares at a 0.44% average premium, with 2.56% of fares missing.
Far-out bookings maintained 100% incidence of higher OTA pricing and the highest average premium of 0.65%.

mse_highlights.line_content: Over 95% of itineraries on MSE were priced below the website last week, delivering an average discount of 0.08% with stable trends.
Long-haul routes saw MSE fares exceed web prices for 2.27% of itineraries, with an average markup of 0.72%.
Non-Poland origins recorded a rise in higher MSE listings to 3.51%, up 1.72ppt week-over-week, indicating emerging price discrepancies.

mse_summary_high_level_comparison.line_content: MSE did not list 0.67% of fares last week, a slight 0.23ppt increase versus the prior week.
Routes with matching fares accounted for 2.70% of listings, remaining essentially flat week-over-week.
MSE offered lower fares on 95.96% of itineraries, delivering a stable 0.08% average discount.
Only 0.67% of itineraries were priced higher on MSE, averaging a 0.73% premium down 0.21ppt week-over-week.

mse_summary_by_region.line_content: 95.76% of short-haul routes were cheaper on MSE with a 0.08% average discount, up 0.17ppt week-over-week.
97.73% of long-haul itineraries were lower priced, but higher-priced cases rose to 2.27%, indicating increased volatility.

mse_summary_by_point_of_origin.line_content: Routes from Poland maintained 96.40% lower pricing on MSE with a 0.08% average discount and only 0.26% higher listings.
Non-PL markets saw the lower fare share fall to 91.23%, with higher-priced listings rising to 3.51% at a 0.70% premium.

mse_summary_by_booking_window.line_content: 95.18% of close-in itineraries were cheaper on MSE with a 0.07% average discount and higher-priced occurrences at 0.64%.
97.76% of far-out bookings were lower priced on MSE with a 0.09% average discount and full availability.

gds_highlights.line_content: Nearly 99% of itineraries on GDS were priced above the website last week, carrying an average 0.59% premium.
1.12% of routes lacked any GDS offer last week, more than doubling from 0.44%, signaling emerging distribution gaps.
Far-out bookings had a 0.76% GDS markup compared to 0.51% for close-in, indicating stronger premiums on advance purchases.

gds_summary_high_level_comparison.line_content: Unavailability on GDS rose to 1.12% last week from 0.44%, though gaps remain below 1.3% of itineraries.
No itineraries were priced identically between the website and GDS, reflecting zero parity offerings.
98.88% of itineraries carried a GDS premium, slightly down from 99.56% the prior week.
GDS never undercut the website, with 0% of itineraries priced lower in the latest period.

gds_summary_by_region.line_content: 98.76% of short-haul routes were higher priced on GDS with a 0.65% average premium and 1.24% unavailability.
All long-haul routes were marked up on GDS at a minimal 0.04% premium with full availability.

gds_summary_by_point_of_origin.line_content: Poland origins saw 99.49% of itineraries on GDS at a 0.65% premium, with offers missing for just 0.51% of routes.
Non-PL markets had 94.64% GDS markups at a 0.10% premium and a 5.36% unavailability rate.

gds_summary_by_booking_window.line_content: 98.40% of close-in itineraries carried a GDS premium of 0.51%, with 1.60% of offerings unavailable.
Far-out itineraries were 100% marked up on GDS at a 0.76% premium with full availability.
